reasoning: The critique targets a fairly central pillar of the post’s rebuttal to compute bottlenecks: that abundant cognitive labor can substitute for compute enough to avoid a hard ceiling and sustain rapid software progress. Pointing out serial experiment–feedback dependencies directly challenges the implicit “parallelize your way out” intuition behind several examples (better experiments, early stopping, idea generation). However, it only partially refutes the position because the post also leans on other mechanisms (e.g., parallel exploration across many experiment branches, extrapolation from smaller runs, stack optimization that reduces per-iteration compute, and alternative ‘routes’ to progress), and serial dependencies don’t imply research is mostly serial. The critique is largely correct about irreducible wall-clock constraints from runtime and information dependencies, though it overstates with claims like “cannot parallelize away” in absolute terms. It is clear, focused on a single issue, and contains little to no irrelevant material.
title: Serial dependencies in research create bottlenecks that cognitive labor cannot parallelize away
